events.event_description: U.S. retail gasoline prices averaged $3.31 per gallon, which is 13% lower than the previous year, driven by weak global demand and increased non-OPEC+ production.
events.citation: Heading into the holiday weekend, the retail price for all formulations of regular gasoline in the United States averaged $3.31 per gallon (gal) on August 26, 2024, 13% lower than this time last year. The decrease in prices paid at the pump was driven by weak growth in global and U.S. petroleum product demand, continued crude oil production growth from countries outside of OPEC+, and China's slowing economy.

events.event_description: OPEC+ members announced extension of crude oil production cuts into 2025 to balance global supply and demand.
events.citation: On June 2, 2024, OPEC+ members announced that most of their crude oil production cuts will extend into 2025 in an attempt to balance global oil supply with demand.

events.event_description: China's economic slowdown in 2024 led to slower crude oil demand growth, putting downward pressure on global oil prices.
events.citation: Crude oil demand growth in China, the world's top crude oil importer, has been slower in 2024 compared with previous years due to an economic slowdown, putting downward pressure on prices.

events.event_description: Storm-related refinery outages caused slight price increases in the Midwest region.
events.citation: In July, Midwest prices increased slightly due to storm-related refinery outages.

events.event_description: Hurricane Debby made landfall in Florida and moved up the East Coast, but did not significantly affect refinery activity or petroleum demand.
events.citation: Gulf Coast oil production and refining was threatened by Hurricane Debby, which made landfall in Florida on August 5, before easing and moving up the East Coast, but the storm did not significantly affect refinery activity or petroleum demand.
